title: Brief Resolved Unexplained Events 2.0 (BRUE 2.0) Criteria for Infants
description: Classifies unexplained events and improves on the original BRUE criteria by providing sophisticated risk prediction models for serious underlying conditions and event recurrence in infants <1 year old. Uses derived models to predict risk of serious diagnosis and recurrent events.

parameters.name: age_under_1_year
parameters.description: Is the infant less than 1 year old?

parameters.name: asymptomatic_on_presentation
parameters.description: Is the infant asymptomatic on presentation (no URI symptoms, no fever)?

parameters.name: no_explanation_after_exam
parameters.description: No explanation for event after history and physical exam?

parameters.name: sudden_brief_resolved_episode
parameters.description: History of sudden, brief, and now resolved episode?

parameters.name: breathing_changes
parameters.description: Episode included absent, decreased, or irregular breathing?

parameters.name: tone_changes
parameters.description: Episode included marked change in tone (hyper or hypotonia)?

parameters.name: altered_responsiveness
parameters.description: Episode included altered level of responsiveness?

parameters.name: age_in_days
parameters.description: Age of infant in days (for risk prediction models)

parameters.name: history_similar_event

result.name: brue_2_0_assessment
result.description: BRUE 2.0 assessment with risk predictions for serious conditions and recurrence

ranges.interpretation: The event does not meet the criteria for Brief Resolved Unexplained Event (BRUE). Consider alternative diagnoses and appropriate evaluation based on clinical presentation.

ranges.description: BRUE with very low risk for serious condition or recurrence
ranges.interpretation: Meets BRUE criteria with very low risk (<2%) for serious underlying condition and low recurrence risk. Appropriate for home management with family education and routine follow-up.

ranges.description: BRUE with low risk for serious condition or recurrence
ranges.interpretation: Meets BRUE criteria with low risk (2-10%) for serious underlying condition. Consider brief observation, family education, and shared decision-making about diagnostic testing.

ranges.description: BRUE with moderate risk for serious condition or recurrence
ranges.interpretation: Meets BRUE criteria with moderate risk (10-20%) for serious underlying condition. Consider extended monitoring, selective diagnostic testing, and close follow-up.

ranges.description: BRUE with high risk for serious condition or recurrence
ranges.interpretation: Meets BRUE criteria with high risk (>20%) for serious underlying condition. Requires comprehensive evaluation, hospitalization consideration, and extensive diagnostic workup.

references: Tieder JS, Bonkowsky JL, Etzel RA, et al. Brief resolved unexplained events (formerly apparent life-threatening events) and evaluation of lower-risk infants. Pediatrics. 2016;137(5):e20160590. doi: 10.1542/peds.2016-0590.

Merritt JL, Quinonez RA, Bonkowsky JL, et al. A framework for evaluation of the higher-risk infant after a brief resolved unexplained event. Pediatrics. 2021;148(1):e2021050798. doi: 10.1542/peds.2021-050798.

Ramgopal S, Karim SA, Subramanian S, Kaderli AA, Fitzgerald M, Ramesh A. Epidemiology of brief resolved unexplained events: a systematic review. Arch Dis Child. 2019;104(11):1074-1081. doi: 10.1136/archdischild-2018-316866.
formula: Risk of Serious Condition = [e^x / (1 + e^x)] * 100, where x = -2.9 - 0.0046*(Age in days) + 1.22*(History of similar event) + 0.35*(Abnormal medical history). Risk of Recurrence calculated using additional factors including multiple event clusters, prematurity, and specific event characteristics.
notes: BRUE 2.0 improves on the original BRUE criteria by providing quantitative risk prediction
Uses derived models to predict risk of serious underlying diagnosis and event recurrence
Provides more nuanced risk stratification than the original binary low-risk/higher-risk classification
Helps guide shared decision-making about diagnostic testing and hospitalization
Risk models are based on multi-center validation studies
Particularly useful for infants who don't clearly fit into the original BRUE lower-risk category
Incorporates age in days as a continuous variable rather than categorical cutoffs
Addresses limitations of the original AAP guidelines regarding risk stratification
